problems.question: If an observer moves toward a stationary sound source, what happens to the perceived frequency?
problems.hint: Approaching the source compresses the wavefronts.
problems.detailed: When the observer moves toward the source, the wavefronts reach the observer more frequently. So the observed frequency **increases**.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: If a source moves away from a stationary observer, what happens to the observed frequency?
problems.hint: Think in terms of stretching the wavefronts.
problems.detailed: A receding source makes wavefronts stretch out, so the observer receives waves less frequently. Hence the observed frequency **decreases**.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Which effect describes the change in frequency due to relative motion between source and observer?
problems.hint: The effect dealing with motion and frequency shifts is named after a scientist.
problems.detailed: The **Doppler effect** is exactly the phenomenon in which frequency (or wavelength) changes due to motion of source, observer, or both.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: If both source and observer are moving toward each other, what is the general trend in observed frequency?
problems.detailed: When both move toward each other, waves are compressed more strongly, so observed frequency is **higher** than emitted frequency.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Which of the following variables appear in the Doppler effect formula for sound?
problems.hint: Think of how both source motion and observer motion affect frequency plus wave speed matters.
problems.detailed: The general Doppler formula includes the wave speed in medium, the velocity of the observer, and the velocity of the source. So all of them matter.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov
